<p><strong>Small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs)</strong> contribute significantly to economies around the world (see sidebar, “What are SMEs?”). In OECD countries, SMEs account for about 99 percent of firms and 70 percent of all jobs,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7fb1e870-3621-4fc9-af7d-e9946d1ed95a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span digitalised economy</em>, OECD, June 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> and they contribute more than 50 percent of GDP in high-income countries worldwide.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> But between February 2020 and April 2021, 70 to 80 percent of SMEs across 32 countries lost between 30 and 50 percent of their revenues.<span aria-describedby="f7a81516-a960-456f-b3fe-339739ab1986"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span back better,”</em> OECD, April 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>What are SMEs?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>The term <em>small and medium-size enterprise</em> (SME) refers to a broad swathe of companies, ranging from single-proprietor businesses to those with hundreds of employees and tens (or hundreds) of millions of dollars in revenue.</p>
<p>The precise definition of an SME varies by country but typically excludes large multinationals, state-owned enterprises, and conglomerates. For instance, the European Union defines an SME as an enterprise with fewer than 250 employees and turnover of less than €50 million or a balance sheet total of less than €43 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="10415aa7-cb99-4758-a7e4-72f725e1219e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="10415aa7-cb99-4758-a7e4-72f725e1219e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“SME definition,” European Commission, last reviewed October 25, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> In Canada, SMEs are enterprises with fewer than 500 employees.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="01705329-dd52-4ad4-84ba-4d619f3fffe3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="01705329-dd52-4ad4-84ba-4d619f3fffe3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“10 things you (probably) didn’t know about Canadian SMEs,” Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC), accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> And Singapore classifies SMEs as enterprises with fewer than 200 employees or with annual sales turnover of less than $100 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="080e8689-4300-45b2-9736-288cc47ae101"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="080e8689-4300-45b2-9736-288cc47ae101" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Topline estimates for all enterprises and SMEs, annual,” Singapore Department of Statistics, July 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Because they understand that threats to SMEs are threats to economies and societies, governments around the world have made supporting SMEs a priority throughout the COVID-19 pandemic through programs such as direct financial assistance, public guarantees on loans, and tax relief.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9743db70-196d-4d38-9215-5917a1ffda84"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9743db70-196d-4d38-9215-5917a1ffda84" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>IMFBlog</em>, “How countries are helping small businesses survive COVID-19,” blog entry by Esha Chhabra, Yingjie Fan, and Kazuko Shirono, March 9, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> While such financial support is beneficial, it does not necessarily set up firms to thrive in the long term and to combat the many converging challenges they’re facing, including pressure to decarbonize, internationalize, keep up with digitalization, and secure the right talent. In addition, many of these supports are on the verge of expiring.</p>
<p>Indeed, a Canadian study showed that the most effective way to support SMEs is by pairing financial support with advisory services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="535956ab-22f2-4b29-89a7-e78d4c4b1fa3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="535956ab-22f2-4b29-89a7-e78d4c4b1fa3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Measuring BDC’s impact on its clients</em>, Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC), July 2013.</span></span></span></a></span> One way to provide this dual support is through National Champion Programmes. Such programs typically work to identify SMEs with high growth potential and provide them with the one-on-one support they need to realize this potential over a defined period of time. Support could include building capabilities (such as digital, marketing, and leadership skills), providing advice from experts on how to navigate the market, guiding transformation efforts, and arranging introductions and networking opportunities.</p>
<p>A handful of existing programs and research from countries around the world—Canada, France, Malaysia, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States—reveal several best practices for governments looking to support SMEs through the challenges they face. Specifically, these programs suggest that governments can help set up SMEs to thrive well into the future by focusing on midsize companies, employing a rigorous selection process, targeting specific groups and tailoring solutions to their needs, providing incentives for commitment, and partnering with the private sector.</p>
<h2>Challenges and opportunities for SMEs today</h2>
<p>The imperatives facing SMEs a few years ago have become more pronounced as the world shifts to the next normal, presenting both challenges and opportunities.</p>
<h3>Keeping up with digitalization</h3>
<p>Most of the world is working to digitalize, a trend that has accelerated over the course of the pandemic, and SMEs are at risk of being left behind.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>A July 2020 survey of executives reveals a rapid shift toward interacting with customers through digital channels, with adoption rates years ahead of where they were in previous surveys. The shift is particularly pronounced in Asia–Pacific, where the <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever">share of digital consumer interactions has advanced by four years</a>, higher than the global average.</p>
<p>The shift to digital persists across countries and categories, as consumers in most parts of the world are engaging less with retailers outside the home. <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/a-global-view-of-how-consumer-behavior-is-changing-amid-covid-19">The online customer base across countries for food and household products, for instance, has grown by more than 30 percent</a>, on average, since before the pandemic.</p>
<p>While such growth certainly comes with benefits, these benefits have disproportionately accrued to larger businesses. <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/twenty-five-years-of-digitization-ten-insights-into-how-to-play-it-right">The top decile of companies by size in digital channels capture 60 to 95 percent of digital revenues</a>. And small firms remain less digitalized than medium-size firms—and medium-size firms less than large firms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f681dca7-a433-4e46-85e6-828be91f3b35"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f681dca7-a433-4e46-85e6-828be91f3b35" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Digital tools and practices: SME access and uptake,” in <em>The digital transformation of SMEs</em>, OECD, February 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Behind this reality is the fact that digital solutions are often designed for large enterprises and are difficult to scale down for SMEs. In Singapore, for example, 56 percent of respondents to a survey reported that digitalization is too expensive for SMEs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5dc0733f-413c-49d0-9a60-6a02c57ce4d4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5dc0733f-413c-49d0-9a60-6a02c57ce4d4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Hariz Baharudin, “Over half of SMEs in Singapore blame digitalisation delay on coronavirus,” <em>Straits Times</em>, October 21, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> The effects could be more significant for underrepresented segments; in the United Kingdom, for example, a report found that female-led SMEs are 20 percent more likely to opt out of digital solutions to improve productivity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="13ce885b-b8ae-4a87-b53e-7902b9347a15"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="13ce885b-b8ae-4a87-b53e-7902b9347a15" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Accelerating SME recovery to unlock £140bn boost to UK economy,” NatWest Group, March 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Internationalizing strategically</h3>
<p>Several studies reveal that SMEs need to internationalize to grow,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7742a956-3330-4170-bb26-107a2911bd77"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7742a956-3330-4170-bb26-107a2911bd77" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kulondwa Safari, “Contribution of internationalisation to SME growth: Evidence from the Kenyan manufacturing sector,” <em>Economics and Business</em>, December 2020, Volume 34, Number 1; Fury Khristianty Fitriyah, Sofik Handoyo, and Ivan Yudianto, “Critical success factors for the internationalisation of small–medium enterprises in Indonesia,” <em>Cogent Business & Management</em>, 2021, Volume 8, Number 1; Lucia Naldi, “Growth through internationalization: A knowledge perspective on SMEs,” Jönköping International Business School, 2008.</span></span></span></a></span> but they often struggle to expand outside their home market or to do so strategically. Even prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, high-potential SMEs in many markets found success domestically, but their potential was capped by the size of their local market. Unlike large companies, many SMEs don’t have the resources to conduct extensive market research before expanding into new markets, instead following opportunities and growing only marginally.</p>
<p>In the European Union, nearly all of the 20 percent of small businesses with e-commerce sales sell within their own economy. Fewer than half of these businesses—representing only 8 percent of the overall market—sell in other EU countries. Only 4 percent sell outside of the European Union. A similar trend is true among medium-size firms.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1f373fd2-7497-4768-b7d0-646f8b7dab22"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1f373fd2-7497-4768-b7d0-646f8b7dab22" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“SMEs in the online platform economy,” in <em>The digital transformation of SMEs</em>, OECD, February 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> In the United Kingdom, SMEs that have ambitious growth targets for the next five years have twice as much turnover from exports, with nearly 40 percent of their sales coming from online channels.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4b6f97e2-2088-41a1-b79b-1882a269c74e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4b6f97e2-2088-41a1-b79b-1882a269c74e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Accelerating SME recovery,” March 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Uncertainties about overseas markets brought on by the pandemic have made internationalization more difficult. Indeed, in a survey in Singapore, 84 percent of SMEs stated that they had delayed their internationalization plans because of the pandemic and the challenges it has exacerbated.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8ac8080d-c52f-4b20-bdb1-9eab34c84a42"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8ac8080d-c52f-4b20-bdb1-9eab34c84a42" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Over half of SMEs in Singapore,” October 21, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, global supply chain issues have hit SMEs hard and have set back export growth. A June 2020 survey in the United States revealed that 45 percent of small businesses had experienced disruptions in supply chains.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5bb1f74b-c361-4d2d-a8b4-27c97ab49191"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5bb1f74b-c361-4d2d-a8b4-27c97ab49191" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Coronavirus (COVID-19): SME policy responses</em>, OECD, July 15, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> And in many cases, leading firms have handed risks down the supply chain to vulnerable SMEs in developing countries, causing job losses and even bankruptcies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="12b1fac8-cb65-4078-b522-be87927a48df"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="12b1fac8-cb65-4078-b522-be87927a48df" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>COVID-19: The great lockdown and its impact on small businesses</em>, International Trade Centre, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Delivering on decarbonization commitments</h3>
<p>Many governments are ramping up efforts to decarbonize. In the United States, President Joe Biden announced a target for the country to achieve a 50 to 52 percent reduction from 2005 levels in economy-wide net greenhouse gas pollution by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1ddb656-d95f-4bf1-9291-7903d1287bd7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1ddb656-d95f-4bf1-9291-7903d1287bd7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Fact sheet: President Biden sets 2030 greenhouse gas pollution reduction target aimed at creating good-paying union jobs and securing U.S. leadership on clean energy technologies,” The White House, April 22, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The European Union aims to have net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0e9a3935-4a84-4ce0-82aa-afafad523213"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0e9a3935-4a84-4ce0-82aa-afafad523213" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“2050 long-term strategy,” European Commission, accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> And at the 2021 UN Climate Change Conference (COP26), countries from around the world agreed on a resolution to cut emissions—albeit falling short of the efforts needed to limit the temperature increase to 1.5°C.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8cf2a93d-5b5b-49d8-8098-6d04ca7baed7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8cf2a93d-5b5b-49d8-8098-6d04ca7baed7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Libby Brooks, Damian Carrington, and Fiona Harvey, “Cop26 ends in climate agreement despite India watering down coal resolution,” <em>Guardian</em>, November 13, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>However, according to a survey by YouGov for energy firm World Kinect Energy Services, 40 percent of SMEs in the United Kingdom haven’t made a sustainability plan—and 30 percent don’t intend to.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0571b770-b48a-46c3-95a7-583d6b31514e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0571b770-b48a-46c3-95a7-583d6b31514e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Vetter, “30% of U.K. small firms have ‘no plans’ to become sustainable, survey finds,” <em>Forbes</em>, February 15, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Indeed, SMEs are less well equipped than larger companies to decarbonize. The survey revealed that 29 percent of SMEs say the pandemic has thwarted sustainability efforts by forcing companies to focus on survival. Furthermore, SMEs may not have the resources to tackle such efforts. And while many decarbonization programs allow companies to realize cost savings relatively quickly, the up-front investments required can hinder SMEs from pursuing them.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ddb43c33-def6-41ce-accd-099cb8b555c6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ddb43c33-def6-41ce-accd-099cb8b555c6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kealy Herman and Emily Wasley, “Net zero: Are SMEs the missing link in the chain?,” WSP, November 12, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Acquiring critical talent</h3>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Lack of the right talent and capabilities has thwarted the ability of SMEs to manage all of the challenges they face.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Lack of the right talent and capabilities has thwarted the ability of SMEs to manage all of the above challenges. Indeed, SMEs tend to struggle to acquire digital talent: 40 percent of respondents to a survey in Singapore stated they lack the digital skills to successfully adopt new technologies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c1d359c7-6990-4213-b29f-fc55acc91d5a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c1d359c7-6990-4213-b29f-fc55acc91d5a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Over half of SMEs in Singapore,” October 21, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Also in Singapore, the struggle to expand internationally is attributed to three primary challenges: trouble attracting the right talent, limited financial resources, and unfamiliarity with the regulatory environment overseas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ab501808-8b49-44a0-b553-7df10c0d1160"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ab501808-8b49-44a0-b553-7df10c0d1160" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Expanding overseas still not an easy task for SMEs,” Enterprise Singapore, May 28, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> And a lack of in-house expertise can inhibit the decarbonization efforts of SMEs. SMEs also tend to have smaller R&D departments than larger firms and finance functions that focus more on accounting than strategy, potentially making it difficult to grow.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c429c8d0-55c9-43ca-a18c-e31bf9057fcb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c429c8d0-55c9-43ca-a18c-e31bf9057fcb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Access to innovation assets,” in <em>SME and entrepreneurship outlook 2019</em>, OECD, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The “Great Attrition” is likely to upend the ways all businesses think about talent. Between April and September 2021, more than 19 million US workers quit their jobs. And according to <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours">a recent McKinsey survey</a>, 40 percent of respondents are at least somewhat likely to quit in the next few months. This trend could calcify talent challenges for SMEs—or present an opportunity to attract talent leaving other roles.</p>
<h2>Five lessons for supporting SMEs through National Champion Programmes</h2>
<p>National Champion Programmes go beyond financial interventions to provide nonfinancial support—such as advisory, transformation, capability-building, and networking opportunities—to help high-potential SMEs tackle challenges and achieve their goals. Such programs have proved to be an effective way for governments and other interested institutions to assist SMEs. Indeed, a program in Malaysia has helped facilitate an export increase of 4.9 billion ringgit (approximately $1.16 billion) across 275 companies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6084b522-1b2f-48c0-8dee-73d11ea3c0f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6084b522-1b2f-48c0-8dee-73d11ea3c0f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Karyn Anne, “Springboard for mid-tier companies to grow exports,” <em>Star</em>, March 26, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> And the first participants in a program in Singapore expect to achieve 20 percent year-over-year growth over the next three years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f6d8b33-3e94-4fcc-b8c0-df08a3b8574b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f6d8b33-3e94-4fcc-b8c0-df08a3b8574b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Opening remarks by Minister Chan Chun Sing at the press conference for the sectoral company visit to AEM Singapore,” Ministry of Trade and Industry Singapore, September 14, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>National Champion Programmes around the world reveal a handful of lessons about unlocking growth and innovation that could help these companies not only weather the current crisis but also overcome the compounding challenges they face.</p>
<h3>Focusing on midsize companies can maximize impact</h3>
<p>Existing programs have demonstrated that programs can achieve the most impact within the realm of SMEs by focusing on midsize companies. These companies have a disproportionate impact on economic outcomes. They also tend to have a demonstrated track record of success, including an ability and willingness to grow and a strong financial history, making them more likely to be able to implement advisory support.</p>
<p>Indeed, in Canada, midsize companies constitute 1.6 percent of all firms, yet they contribute 12 percent of GDP and 16 percent of employment—and they account for 11 percent of all exporters and 17 percent of export value.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="474598a0-ee11-477a-8591-89c468882cda"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="474598a0-ee11-477a-8591-89c468882cda" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>High-impact firms: Accelerating Canadian competitiveness</em>, BDC, May 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> Midsize companies in Malaysia, which represent 2 percent of all firms, are critical economic players; they contribute about 40 percent of the country’s GDP and employ more than 16 percent of the workforce.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="785b5022-c57a-4e85-9aae-71363d8a2d59"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="785b5022-c57a-4e85-9aae-71363d8a2d59" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Mid-tier companies development programme (MTCDP),” Malaysia External Trade Development Corporation, accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The highest-performing companies, including midtier companies, contribute even more, achieving 20 percent year-over-year growth<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e256de9a-23f6-4fb5-964e-debf4d417223"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e256de9a-23f6-4fb5-964e-debf4d417223" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“High-growth enterprises,” in <em>Eurostat–OECD manual on business demography statistics</em>, Eurostat and OECD, 2007.</span></span></span></a></span> and accounting for 50 percent of new jobs and sales, particularly in the manufacturing and services sectors.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8930fdf9-bd8e-4b15-a284-71f53165de87"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8930fdf9-bd8e-4b15-a284-71f53165de87" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“High-growth firms: Facts, fiction, and policy options for emerging economies,” World Bank, November 16, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> By targeting these companies, then, National Champion Programmes stand to have an outsize impact on the country’s economy and workforce.</p>
<h3>Personalized outreach can help identify and recruit the companies with the highest potential</h3>
<p>Existing programs have demonstrated the importance of targeting companies with high potential through rigorous selection processes—including getting to know them one on one.</p>
<p>Companies with the highest potential tend to have the greatest chance of delivering the desired economic benefits, including increased revenues, exports, GDP, and employment. To ensure support goes to those with the highest potential, some governments have employed stringent selection processes that test for this potential, looking at quantitative data about the company and its history, as well as qualitative criteria such as the scale of ambition and the presence of growth mindsets.</p>
<p>For example, Scale-up SG, a 12- to 18-month program in Singapore, helps selected high-growth companies scale to become major employers and leaders in their field. The criteria for selection for this program include that the company have a track record of growth; leadership with strong ambitions and a clear growth strategy; high potential for economic spin-offs, such as creating job opportunities; and bandwidth to dedicate significant management time and resources to accelerate growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b20d8ac1-1f00-4d80-9bd4-62259757fe05"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b20d8ac1-1f00-4d80-9bd4-62259757fe05" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Scale-up SG,” Enterprise Singapore, accessed March 3, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>To attract these high-potential companies, existing programs have found that they need to be able to understand each SME’s unique needs and address them on a case-by-case basis. Rather than taking an automated or mass-outreach approach, program representatives reach out personally to companies, building relationships with them to ensure the program is a good fit, to understand their starting point, and to explain how the program will benefit them. Such tailored outreach is particularly relevant for ensuring inclusion of minority- and women-led businesses.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7cf3b301-4595-48ac-b3a0-f5de2db4afa6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7cf3b301-4595-48ac-b3a0-f5de2db4afa6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Accelerating SME recovery,” March 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Targeting a specific group of companies and tailoring programs to their needs</h3>
<p>While SMEs might be similar in scale, they span nearly all sectors and vary in capabilities, challenges, and objectives—therefore requiring varying kinds of support. However, SMEs are not always well equipped to identify the type of support they need. A report from the United Kingdom found that SMEs use about 20 different sources to find the right program, and 72 percent of them research for at least 30 hours a week for three weeks before deciding to join.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="96e44da2-2876-488c-b003-7ac78684acfa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="96e44da2-2876-488c-b003-7ac78684acfa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Accelerating SME recovery,” March 30, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Existing programs reveal that the most effective programs tailor support to companies’ specific needs by doing two things:</p>
<p>First, they limit their scope by targeting specific groups of SMEs that have shared objectives. These objectives often relate to the challenges SMEs are currently facing, including internationalization and digitalization. For instance, Malaysia’s Mid-Tier Companies Development Programme (MTCDP) focuses on midsize companies in the manufacturing and service industries aiming to grow exports of goods and services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a11d677-62a9-4d26-91f9-e48b735855a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a11d677-62a9-4d26-91f9-e48b735855a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“MTCDP application criteria,” Mid-Tier Companies Development Programme, accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> The Industry 4.0 Human Capital Initiative (IHCI) program in Singapore targets manufacturing companies that are looking to digitalize their operations and thus focuses on relevant Industry 4.0 applications.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc2fc6d9-4125-419e-ad01-73fb942bf2f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc2fc6d9-4125-419e-ad01-73fb942bf2f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“What is IHCI,” Industry 4.0 Human Capital Initiative, accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Second, they recognize that not all companies—even those within a specific group—have the same needs. Thus, they employ a range of interventions for these companies to choose from, and they support them in navigating the options to create a program that best fits their needs.</p>
<p>MTCDP, for example, begins with a three-month diagnostic phase to identify companies’ most acute needs and relevant interventions. This process comprises a survey that helps reveal export challenges that SMEs are facing, interviews with top management, and a diagnostic clinic during which interventions are ultimately chosen.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5832654e-70ac-464f-80b9-06dded430bc7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5832654e-70ac-464f-80b9-06dded430bc7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Program phases and timeline,” Mid-Tier Companies Development Programme, accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Scale-up SG likewise begins with a “strategize” phase; over four months, companies work to align on growth priorities and develop and commit to a road map for growth and targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b60b7c9-a6e0-400e-94cc-be030d19d1ac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b60b7c9-a6e0-400e-94cc-be030d19d1ac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Scale-up SG programme structure for inaugural run,” Scale-up SG, July 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In Canada, the Growth Driver Program run by the government-owned Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC) provides selected companies across all sectors with formal management training, peer-to-peer networking, and other tailored nonfinancial services. A small team of highly experienced advisers works with firms to assess their needs and identify solutions to their challenges, including planning a multiyear growth outlook and preparing a management plan—as well as providing targeted support for CEOs and leadership teams.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7df01dbf-9313-4b76-aa46-6f03139e7a5c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7df01dbf-9313-4b76-aa46-6f03139e7a5c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>High-impact firms</em>, May 2015.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Pursuing SMEs that are highly committed to making a change</h3>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-right-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>SMEs have diverse needs, and governments have the power to provide support for them.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>National Champion Programmes typically involve a blend of strategic advisory, delivery, and capability-building support. Translating this support into results requires a high level of commitment from SMEs. Programs can use a number of tactics to encourage companies to commit not just to completing the program but to implementing what they learn and making new strategic moves.</p>
<p>For instance, Scale-up SG requires that SMEs pay 20 to 30 percent of program costs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e8ea8af1-bf9e-4de6-8b83-94877a0865fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e8ea8af1-bf9e-4de6-8b83-94877a0865fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Scale-up SG fact sheet,” Ministry of Trade and Industry Singapore, March 1, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> MTCDP in Malaysia similarly requires participants to cover certain costs, such as travel expenses; the program also expects CEOs and senior management to commit to the program for about one day per month over the course of nine months.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="aa70c128-99fd-4b07-a56d-ff7ba187e7b6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="aa70c128-99fd-4b07-a56d-ff7ba187e7b6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“MTCDP application criteria,” accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Tapping the private sector for expertise and access</h3>
<p>SMEs have diverse needs, and the government has the power to convene the different players in an economy to provide this support. Private-sector companies, for instance, can not only lend their expertise to SMEs by acting as advisers; they can also potentially provide them with access to larger clients and investors and help them build capacity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d8f155d6-9c9e-4fd0-aa53-b82f6ecf234c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d8f155d6-9c9e-4fd0-aa53-b82f6ecf234c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Joining forces to leave no one behind,” in <em>Development co-operation report 2018</em>, OECD, December 11, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> Ultimately, these partnerships can put SMEs in a better position to tackle the many challenges they face and to continue to grow.</p>
<p>Detroit Means Business (DMB) in the United States provides an example of such a partnership. DMB is a coalition of more than 60 public, private, and philanthropic organizations; Detroit-based business-support organizations; and civic-minded small-business entrepreneurs. Participants include the City of Detroit, many private-sector institutions, Invest Detroit, and Detroit Economic Growth Corporation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6bc01ca6-2f51-4f1d-b598-e75ab46c01a8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6bc01ca6-2f51-4f1d-b598-e75ab46c01a8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Team,” Detroit Means Business (DMB), accessed December 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> These groups came together early in the COVID-19 pandemic with the goal of helping SMEs survive by giving them access to support, such as financial resources, webinars on time-sensitive topics, and information about personal protective equipment (PPE) and reopening guidelines. As the COVID-19 pandemic has persisted, the coalition has evolved its initiatives, deepening digital capabilities, driving local procurement, and helping individual small businesses grow.</p>
<hr>
<p>SMEs are crucial actors in economies and societies worldwide. These businesses make outsize contributions to GDP, exports, employment, and livelihoods in developed and developing countries alike, but they’re facing increasing threats that could undermine their growth and ability to contribute meaningfully. Learning from existing National Champion Programmes, governments across the globe have an opportunity to help SMEs continue to thrive—through the pandemic and well into the future.</p></div><div type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Beyond financials Helping small and medium size enterprises thrive","displayName":"Beyond financials Helping small and medium size enterprises thrive","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"1791f7f2-0398-480a-bf26-27db2a10c833","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Beyond financials: Helping small and medium-size enterprises thrive"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Helping small and medium-size enterprises thrive"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Small and medium-size enterprises are facing compounding challenges. Governments and other institutions worldwide are launching programs to provide them the advisory support needed to meet the moment."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"Worldwide, governments and other institutions are launching programs to provide SMEs the advisory support needed to overcome compounding challenges."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-01-26T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Audio 1]] [[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSmall and medium-size enterprises (SMEs)\u003c/strong\u003e contribute significantly to economies around the world (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;What are SMEs?\u0026rdquo;). In OECD countries, SMEs account for about 99 percent of firms and 70 percent of all jobs,[[footnote 1]] and they contribute more than 50 percent of GDP in high-income countries worldwide.[[footnote 2]] But between February 2020 and April 2021, 70 to 80 percent of SMEs across 32 countries lost between 30 and 50 percent of their revenues.[[footnote 3]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eBecause they understand that threats to SMEs are threats to economies and societies, governments around the world have made supporting SMEs a priority throughout the COVID-19 pandemic through programs such as direct financial assistance, public guarantees on loans, and tax relief.[[footnote 4]] While such financial support is beneficial, it does not necessarily set up firms to thrive in the long term and to combat the many converging challenges they\u0026rsquo;re facing, including pressure to decarbonize, internationalize, keep up with digitalization, and secure the right talent. In addition, many of these supports are on the verge of expiring.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndeed, a Canadian study showed that the most effective way to support SMEs is by pairing financial support with advisory services.[[footnote 5]] One way to provide this dual support is through National Champion Programmes. Such programs typically work to identify SMEs with high growth potential and provide them with the one-on-one support they need to realize this potential over a defined period of time. Support could include building capabilities (such as digital, marketing, and leadership skills), providing advice from experts on how to navigate the market, guiding transformation efforts, and arranging introductions and networking opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA handful of existing programs and research from countries around the world\u0026mdash;Canada, France, Malaysia, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States\u0026mdash;reveal several best practices for governments looking to support SMEs through the challenges they face. Specifically, these programs suggest that governments can help set up SMEs to thrive well into the future by focusing on midsize companies, employing a rigorous selection process, targeting specific groups and tailoring solutions to their needs, providing incentives for commitment, and partnering with the private sector.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eChallenges and opportunities for SMEs today\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe imperatives facing SMEs a few years ago have become more pronounced as the world shifts to the next normal, presenting both challenges and opportunities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eKeeping up with digitalization\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost of the world is working to digitalize, a trend that has accelerated over the course of the pandemic, and SMEs are at risk of being left behind.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eA July 2020 survey of executives reveals a rapid shift toward interacting with customers through digital channels, with adoption rates years ahead of where they were in previous surveys. The shift is particularly pronounced in Asia\u0026ndash;Pacific, where the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever\"\u003eshare of digital consumer interactions has advanced by four years\u003c/a\u003e, higher than the global average.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe shift to digital persists across countries and categories, as consumers in most parts of the world are engaging less with retailers outside the home. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/a-global-view-of-how-consumer-behavior-is-changing-amid-covid-19\"\u003eThe online customer base across countries for food and household products, for instance, has grown by more than 30 percent\u003c/a\u003e, on average, since before the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile such growth certainly comes with benefits, these benefits have disproportionately accrued to larger businesses. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/twenty-five-years-of-digitization-ten-insights-into-how-to-play-it-right\"\u003eThe top decile of companies by size in digital channels capture 60 to 95 percent of digital revenues\u003c/a\u003e. And small firms remain less digitalized than medium-size firms\u0026mdash;and medium-size firms less than large firms.[[footnote 6]] Behind this reality is the fact that digital solutions are often designed for large enterprises and are difficult to scale down for SMEs. In Singapore, for example, 56 percent of respondents to a survey reported that digitalization is too expensive for SMEs.[[footnote 7]] The effects could be more significant for underrepresented segments; in the United Kingdom, for example, a report found that female-led SMEs are 20 percent more likely to opt out of digital solutions to improve productivity.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInternationalizing strategically\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral studies reveal that SMEs need to internationalize to grow,[[footnote 9]] but they often struggle to expand outside their home market or to do so strategically. Even prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, high-potential SMEs in many markets found success domestically, but their potential was capped by the size of their local market. Unlike large companies, many SMEs don\u0026rsquo;t have the resources to conduct extensive market research before expanding into new markets, instead following opportunities and growing only marginally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the European Union, nearly all of the 20 percent of small businesses with e-commerce sales sell within their own economy. Fewer than half of these businesses\u0026mdash;representing only 8 percent of the overall market\u0026mdash;sell in other EU countries. Only 4 percent sell outside of the European Union. A similar trend is true among medium-size firms.[[footnote 10]] In the United Kingdom, SMEs that have ambitious growth targets for the next five years have twice as much turnover from exports, with nearly 40 percent of their sales coming from online channels.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUncertainties about overseas markets brought on by the pandemic have made internationalization more difficult. Indeed, in a survey in Singapore, 84 percent of SMEs stated that they had delayed their internationalization plans because of the pandemic and the challenges it has exacerbated.[[footnote 12]] Additionally, global supply chain issues have hit SMEs hard and have set back export growth. A June 2020 survey in the United States revealed that 45 percent of small businesses had experienced disruptions in supply chains.[[footnote 13]] And in many cases, leading firms have handed risks down the supply chain to vulnerable SMEs in developing countries, causing job losses and even bankruptcies.[[footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDelivering on decarbonization commitments\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMany governments are ramping up efforts to decarbonize. In the United States, President Joe Biden announced a target for the country to achieve a 50 to 52 percent reduction from 2005 levels in economy-wide net greenhouse gas pollution by 2030.[[footnote 15]] The European Union aims to have net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050.[[footnote 16]] And at the 2021 UN Climate Change Conference (COP26), countries from around the world agreed on a resolution to cut emissions\u0026mdash;albeit falling short of the efforts needed to limit the temperature increase to 1.5\u0026deg;C.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, according to a survey by YouGov for energy firm World Kinect Energy Services, 40 percent of SMEs in the United Kingdom haven\u0026rsquo;t made a sustainability plan\u0026mdash;and 30 percent don\u0026rsquo;t intend to.[[footnote 18]] Indeed, SMEs are less well equipped than larger companies to decarbonize. The survey revealed that 29 percent of SMEs say the pandemic has thwarted sustainability efforts by forcing companies to focus on survival. Furthermore, SMEs may not have the resources to tackle such efforts. And while many decarbonization programs allow companies to realize cost savings relatively quickly, the up-front investments required can hinder SMEs from pursuing them.[[footnote 19]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAcquiring critical talent\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eLack of the right talent and capabilities has thwarted the ability of SMEs to manage all of the above challenges. Indeed, SMEs tend to struggle to acquire digital talent: 40 percent of respondents to a survey in Singapore stated they lack the digital skills to successfully adopt new technologies.[[footnote 20]] Also in Singapore, the struggle to expand internationally is attributed to three primary challenges: trouble attracting the right talent, limited financial resources, and unfamiliarity with the regulatory environment overseas.[[footnote 21]] And a lack of in-house expertise can inhibit the decarbonization efforts of SMEs. SMEs also tend to have smaller R\u0026amp;D departments than larger firms and finance functions that focus more on accounting than strategy, potentially making it difficult to grow.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u0026ldquo;Great Attrition\u0026rdquo; is likely to upend the ways all businesses think about talent. Between April and September 2021, more than 19 million US workers quit their jobs. And according to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/great-attrition-or-great-attraction-the-choice-is-yours\"\u003ea recent McKinsey survey\u003c/a\u003e, 40 percent of respondents are at least somewhat likely to quit in the next few months. This trend could calcify talent challenges for SMEs\u0026mdash;or present an opportunity to attract talent leaving other roles.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eFive lessons for supporting SMEs through National Champion Programmes\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNational Champion Programmes go beyond financial interventions to provide nonfinancial support\u0026mdash;such as advisory, transformation, capability-building, and networking opportunities\u0026mdash;to help high-potential SMEs tackle challenges and achieve their goals. Such programs have proved to be an effective way for governments and other interested institutions to assist SMEs. Indeed, a program in Malaysia has helped facilitate an export increase of 4.9 billion ringgit (approximately $1.16 billion) across 275 companies.[[footnote 23]] And the first participants in a program in Singapore expect to achieve 20 percent year-over-year growth over the next three years.[[footnote 24]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNational Champion Programmes around the world reveal a handful of lessons about unlocking growth and innovation that could help these companies not only weather the current crisis but also overcome the compounding challenges they face.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFocusing on midsize companies can maximize impact\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExisting programs have demonstrated that programs can achieve the most impact within the realm of SMEs by focusing on midsize companies. These companies have a disproportionate impact on economic outcomes. They also tend to have a demonstrated track record of success, including an ability and willingness to grow and a strong financial history, making them more likely to be able to implement advisory support.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIndeed, in Canada, midsize companies constitute 1.6 percent of all firms, yet they contribute 12 percent of GDP and 16 percent of employment\u0026mdash;and they account for 11 percent of all exporters and 17 percent of export value.[[footnote 25]] Midsize companies in Malaysia, which represent 2 percent of all firms, are critical economic players; they contribute about 40 percent of the country\u0026rsquo;s GDP and employ more than 16 percent of the workforce.[[footnote 26]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe highest-performing companies, including midtier companies, contribute even more, achieving 20 percent year-over-year growth[[footnote 27]] and accounting for 50 percent of new jobs and sales, particularly in the manufacturing and services sectors.[[footnote 28]] By targeting these companies, then, National Champion Programmes stand to have an outsize impact on the country\u0026rsquo;s economy and workforce.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePersonalized outreach can help identify and recruit the companies with the highest potential\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExisting programs have demonstrated the importance of targeting companies with high potential through rigorous selection processes\u0026mdash;including getting to know them one on one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompanies with the highest potential tend to have the greatest chance of delivering the desired economic benefits, including increased revenues, exports, GDP, and employment. To ensure support goes to those with the highest potential, some governments have employed stringent selection processes that test for this potential, looking at quantitative data about the company and its history, as well as qualitative criteria such as the scale of ambition and the presence of growth mindsets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor example, Scale-up SG, a 12- to 18-month program in Singapore, helps selected high-growth companies scale to become major employers and leaders in their field. The criteria for selection for this program include that the company have a track record of growth; leadership with strong ambitions and a clear growth strategy; high potential for economic spin-offs, such as creating job opportunities; and bandwidth to dedicate significant management time and resources to accelerate growth.[[footnote 29]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo attract these high-potential companies, existing programs have found that they need to be able to understand each SME\u0026rsquo;s unique needs and address them on a case-by-case basis. Rather than taking an automated or mass-outreach approach, program representatives reach out personally to companies, building relationships with them to ensure the program is a good fit, to understand their starting point, and to explain how the program will benefit them. Such tailored outreach is particularly relevant for ensuring inclusion of minority- and women-led businesses.[[footnote 30]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTargeting a specific group of companies and tailoring programs to their needs\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile SMEs might be similar in scale, they span nearly all sectors and vary in capabilities, challenges, and objectives\u0026mdash;therefore requiring varying kinds of support. However, SMEs are not always well equipped to identify the type of support they need. A report from the United Kingdom found that SMEs use about 20 different sources to find the right program, and 72 percent of them research for at least 30 hours a week for three weeks before deciding to join.[[footnote 31]] Existing programs reveal that the most effective programs tailor support to companies\u0026rsquo; specific needs by doing two things:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, they limit their scope by targeting specific groups of SMEs that have shared objectives. These objectives often relate to the challenges SMEs are currently facing, including internationalization and digitalization. For instance, Malaysia\u0026rsquo;s Mid-Tier Companies Development Programme (MTCDP) focuses on midsize companies in the manufacturing and service industries aiming to grow exports of goods and services.[[footnote 32]] The Industry 4.0 Human Capital Initiative (IHCI) program in Singapore targets manufacturing companies that are looking to digitalize their operations and thus focuses on relevant Industry 4.0 applications.[[footnote 33]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, they recognize that not all companies\u0026mdash;even those within a specific group\u0026mdash;have the same needs. Thus, they employ a range of interventions for these companies to choose from, and they support them in navigating the options to create a program that best fits their needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMTCDP, for example, begins with a three-month diagnostic phase to identify companies\u0026rsquo; most acute needs and relevant interventions. This process comprises a survey that helps reveal export challenges that SMEs are facing, interviews with top management, and a diagnostic clinic during which interventions are ultimately chosen.[[footnote 34]] Scale-up SG likewise begins with a \u0026ldquo;strategize\u0026rdquo; phase; over four months, companies work to align on growth priorities and develop and commit to a road map for growth and targets.[[footnote 35]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn Canada, the Growth Driver Program run by the government-owned Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC) provides selected companies across all sectors with formal management training, peer-to-peer networking, and other tailored nonfinancial services. A small team of highly experienced advisers works with firms to assess their needs and identify solutions to their challenges, including planning a multiyear growth outlook and preparing a management plan\u0026mdash;as well as providing targeted support for CEOs and leadership teams.[[footnote 36]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003ePursuing SMEs that are highly committed to making a change\u003c/h3\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eNational Champion Programmes typically involve a blend of strategic advisory, delivery, and capability-building support. Translating this support into results requires a high level of commitment from SMEs. Programs can use a number of tactics to encourage companies to commit not just to completing the program but to implementing what they learn and making new strategic moves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor instance, Scale-up SG requires that SMEs pay 20 to 30 percent of program costs.[[footnote 37]] MTCDP in Malaysia similarly requires participants to cover certain costs, such as travel expenses; the program also expects CEOs and senior management to commit to the program for about one day per month over the course of nine months.[[footnote 38]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTapping the private sector for expertise and access\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSMEs have diverse needs, and the government has the power to convene the different players in an economy to provide this support. Private-sector companies, for instance, can not only lend their expertise to SMEs by acting as advisers; they can also potentially provide them with access to larger clients and investors and help them build capacity.[[footnote 39]] Ultimately, these partnerships can put SMEs in a better position to tackle the many challenges they face and to continue to grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDetroit Means Business (DMB) in the United States provides an example of such a partnership. DMB is a coalition of more than 60 public, private, and philanthropic organizations; Detroit-based business-support organizations; and civic-minded small-business entrepreneurs. Participants include the City of Detroit, many private-sector institutions, Invest Detroit, and Detroit Economic Growth Corporation.[[footnote 40]] These groups came together early in the COVID-19 pandemic with the goal of helping SMEs survive by giving them access to support, such as financial resources, webinars on time-sensitive topics, and information about personal protective equipment (PPE) and reopening guidelines. As the COVID-19 pandemic has persisted, the coalition has evolved its initiatives, deepening digital capabilities, driving local procurement, and helping individual small businesses grow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSMEs are crucial actors in economies and societies worldwide. These businesses make outsize contributions to GDP, exports, employment, and livelihoods in developed and developing countries alike, but they\u0026rsquo;re facing increasing threats that could undermine their growth and ability to contribute meaningfully. Learning from existing National Champion Programmes, governments across the globe have an opportunity to help SMEs continue to thrive\u0026mdash;through the pandemic and well into the future.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
